During my second trip to San Francisco this January, I wandered into Kevin's Noodle House with encouragement from my cousin. Having been to Vietnam, I had very low expectations when it comes to America Vietnamese food. 

I was pretty cold and I ordered Mien Ga Soup.  The decor was oddly authentic to Vietnam itself, not too flashy-acutally looks kind of dive-y. I am not exaggerating when I say that this is the best Vietnamese food I have had since visiting the country itself. My soup broth was delicious, the basil was super fresh, the meat was so tender and they even had authentic fish oil and chili on the side!!

If you like Vietnamese- it is a must!
author: Phoebe L.

description: Pho and chicken wings were both excellent. The house chili sauce and fish sauce were also very good. Busy place with lots of seating but you'll probably have a wait but worth it.
author: Will D.

description:
The best pho place in town! 
Cheap with fast service! 
Number 1 is the way to go for new comers. 

They even have kid size pho for $4.75! And they don't make a big scene if you're older and you just feel like ordering that size!
author: Jessica W.

description:
What can I say, I'm a fan of the Irving Street location. There's parking on the street or you can take Muni to this location. 

The food is always consistent, hot, and quick. You can never go wrong getting Gi Cun and a medium bowl of 22A on a cold day. 

Service is always on point.
author: Christine H.

description: Always a good quick spot for pho. Been coming here for years with the homies. Quick, fast, one of the local pho spot on Irving.  Get #1 with beef on the side for the win. Or one of the rice plates. They also sell tapioca drinks(bobba) here.
author: Thai S.

description:
Sometimes I like my pho basic and dirty, and that's ok in my book (jk, it's really not that dirty!) This pho place is my default and it's a lifesaver! I'm more of a pho ga person, I think the soup tastes cleaner. My usual is the 22C - chicken pho with shrimp. If I'm craving the heavier beef broth I'll get pho tai with the beef raw on the side so I can cook my meat myself.

Been to the Daly City, Walnut Creek and Concord locations also. Yay for uniformity and I can appreciate that it's a family owned business. Perfect for warming up on a cold day or a surefire hangover cure!
author: Bonnie S.

description:
The noodles here are SO yummy!! Really fast service and always friendly.

Not to mention the PRICE IS RIGGGGGHT! seriously though, you'll most likely be full after a small. Good portions of meat and tons of noodles in a nice bowl of perfect broth.

The boy and I usually get number 13-17 or the beef stew, all are to die for.
I try to come everyday if I can convince my boyfriend! 

Only thing I'll say is that the to go orders are pretty much all the same size so you may as well just get a small. We ordered a large and the boy said it was exactly the same size as the small he orders alone so, forgo the large and get a small.

Enjoy!!!!!
author: L. J.

description:
Personally, I've never met Kevin, but in case I ever do, I've prepared a little note for him:

"Kevin, how did you do it?

When I had your chicken noodle soup for the first time this summer in Walnut Creek, I knew there was something about this place. I knew I would be back.

And so you can bet that when I moved to the inner sunset and was down with the cold, Pho Huynh Hiep #2 (I like the way the name rolls off my tongue in my mangled anglicization, like an accelerating chromatic balloon) was the first place I thought of. And it worked.

If Warhol did a Campbell's Soup-esque painting of this chicken soup, it would be -- among many other things -- a completely unironic rendition. Because sometimes I do say 'Mmm-mmm good' when I eat your soup, but not because I've been conditioned by years of cheesy advertisements with jingles. No, this is a pre-TV, visceral reaction.

To be honest, I didn't even know Vietnamese dishes existed besides Pho (before I went to a Pho Huynh Hiep). I mean this from an epistemological standpoint. Can one really say one knows such dishes exist, having never seen or tasted one oneself? Exactly. And how would I ever know, when I'm programmed to say "A large #1 please" at every other restaurant I go to in the States? But something happened that hot summer day, and now I know about Vermicelli plates with Pork, and Vietnamese Rice Combos. If you had a salad, I would eat it. Actually I did. And this exploration of cuisine alone is the most culture I've ever experienced in San Francisco, with the exception of riding the Muni (a beast of its own, to be sure).

Last but not least, 'real artists ship.' That's what Steve Jobs said. Or that's what Steve Jobs said while plagiarizing a la his other favorite quote, 'real artists steal.' Who knows. Regardless of the apocryphal origins of the phrase, you are the embodiment of it. And by that I mean the operational efficiency of this place. It is the perfect balance of tradition (broth) meeting technology (mobile kitchen order relays). And I work in the mobile payments industry, so I have some inkling of what I'm talking about.

Yes, now you know I know you know how to move product. And I know this is true, because you have multiple locations around the bay area, steeped in this very same tradition of brothy excellence.

Hats off to you Kevin. It's good to see people 'doing it right.' And I sincerely believe you help bring the hungry and the lonesome traveller back to humanity, one contemplative bowl of broth at a time... although, I'm pretty sure I'm the only person I've ever seen eating a bowl of chicken soup at closing by himself.

Regardless -- my regards,

-Christophe"
author: Christophe C.

description:
On cold and windy days that often plague the Sunset, I enjoy ducking in here for a large pho-ntastic bowl of noodle soup! This place is casual and draws quite a crowd at dinner times; get here early to get a spot.   For two people, two large soups and one appetizer is around $30 w/ tip - not a bad deal at all!! 

My favorites here are the shrimp spring rolls (boiled shrimp and vermicelli noodles wrapped in rice paper) and the special combo noodle soup w/thin slice of steak, well-done brisket, flank, tendon & beef ball (Đc Bit Bò Viên). The spring rolls are refreshing and feed two (3 rolls in one order). And, a large bowl of soup has a very flavorful broth that is enough for a really hungry person!
author: Shubhra S.

description:
Kevin's Noodle House! Always a good place to get pho, but....

*Food: it seems like they are decreasing in their food size. I ordered a small #13 (raw + cooked beef noodles) and there were hardly any beef pieces. The beef pieces were really small and rough. However, their brother is quite delicious. I like how the broth has a sweet taste to it. 

The portion and beef is sadly...disappointing.

*Services: it was pretty good. We were greeted right away with tea. The waitress came to us pretty quickly as well and ready to take our order. (it was a full house)

*Atmosphere: it was a nice pho place. It didn't seem dirty and it was quite pleasant. The tables/chairs were all spread out in unisons with a counter/cashier on the right side of the room. The kitchen was way back and the bathroom to the left side.
author: Katie P.

description:
Pho can't get any better than on a cold, rainy day.

At Kevin's Noodle House, the service is unbelievably fast, the pho is piping hot, the quality is excellent, the prices are extremely wallet-friendly, and the restaurant is very spacious.

There's a limited selection of appetizers, but the selection for pho noodle, vermicelli, rice plates and drinks is huge! In addition, the noodle soups come in three sizes (small, medium or large) that can satisfy your different hunger levels.

I'd love Kevin's Noodle House 100X more if they served garlic noodles! Even though they don't, I will definitely be back if I'm hungry, in the neighborhood, and don't want to spend more than $10 total for a meal.
author: Priscilla W.

description:
Wonderful tasty food served in large portions at modest prices.  Dishes are made from scratch and fresh at the time of order.  

The Pho Tai is flavorful and filling and can be prepared with your choice of meat.

The staff is friendly and helpful.  Be sure to ask for suggestions if you are unsure what to order.
author: Ann V.

description:
Great, solid Vietnamese soup.  Always packed.   Much better than the PPQ across the street, imo.  

Fresh spring rolls are lovely, Bun is fresh and wonderful.  Shrimp is smaller than I am used to (gulf of mexico) but well grilled.  The chicken is my favorite, which is unusual.  it has no gristly bits and is well seasoned.

Very fast service.
author: B K.

description: One my favorite pho places in SF !!! Portions are good and number 1 the pho and Vietnamese coffee is on point ! Parking is a little tough during busy hours but definitely worth it !
author: danny h.

description: Delicious pho, fast service, and cheap (less than $10 pp)! I had the medium #17 pho (thin steak) with extra cilantro and onions. Serving size was generous and the pho definitely hit the spot! Lots of seating but the place fills up.
author: Neel P.

description:
I think this is Pho review number 115 for me. You sort of lose track after 100 bowls, (actually maybe thousands) in over 100 places. There is a book title somewhere in there. 

I have been to Pho Hunyh Hiep 5  - one of the other Kevin's Noodle Houses - many times as my local go-to Pho diner when i worked in Concord near the Park and Shop mall where it was located.

Number 2 here is similar in set up, with about 3 rows of tables in a pretty large room that has about 20 tables and the same familiar drill at most Pho specialty places. 

Here, for the first time on Yelp, are the instructions from the standard Vietnamese Pho Restaurant Operating Manual, that secret and sacred document revealed here in public for the first time to educate and expand the appreciation of the growing Low Fan (foreigner) Pho loving masses: 

1. Number tables sequentially so you can put it on the guests check and manage the logistics of payment after the meal. The numbers must be in standard gold and black sticker decals of regulation height and placement, centered on the wall next to the table, or affixed prominently on the side of the silver napkin holder or silver table accessories caddy if there is no nearby wall. 

2. The guest check must be in 2 parts, with a detachable small bottom that you throw randomly on the table, where you can write the table number that matches the table, and the top part of the check, which you leave at the cashier in random cascaded piles. 

3. Have the standard Chinese/Vietnamese silver table caddy for: 
a) Faux marble plastic beige chopsticks (must hold at least 50, try green/red if you want to look different, but not recommended) 
b) Soup spoons, must be plastic with faux blue porcelain appearance, rice or fish design
Options C - room for red squeeze bottle of Hoy Sin Sauce and off the 99 Ranch store shelf Sri Racha Tung Ot sauce, soy sauce, and glass dish for hot chili oil with silver lid and plastic spoon. If not room in caddy, place on table as if there was. 
Option D - add room for mini-saucer for condiments, i.e. Hoy Sin sauce and Sri Racha, to dip your Pho meat to season and eat, instead of dumping all of that into the broth and spoiling the 4 hour broth flavor you tried to create 
(but let Low Fan squeeze into broth, because that is what they are trained to do with catsup bottle on French Fries, or mustard on Hot Dogs, or thousand Island on Salads) 

4. Have 1 man serve as arbitrator of guest seating, and order taking. Must know menu by number and name, and good at pointing. Must know how to decipher Low Fan pronunciation in Vietnamese of Pho (Foh instead of Fa-uh). 

5. Substitute for man only when necessary with young cute girl (preferable a relative) who is tough and doesn't smile, otherwise leave women at cashier desk to handle money and sort out guest checks (preferable matriarch from Vietnam with poor English skills). Secret is, women are observant, so even though guests don't know their table number, she does, and can find the right check within 3 attempts, max, usually in 1 try.  

6. Have older male staff as food runners, because their skin isn't as sensitive.  Must be able to handle hot bowls of soup, possibly with thumb over lip into bowl, for balance. No English skills required, in fact avoid. Refer to #4 man/arbitrator for questions. Cart/bussing skills a plus. 

I ordered Pho Tai Gau, medium. The broth was pretty good, a decent balance of sweet and sour. Not too mucked up with extras, but nice onions. The noodles were good, clumped as is typical, but not falling apart, or milky or mushy. The meat was average in quantity, but it was tougher than my now standard near Concord,  Pho Lee Hoa Phat (which also has several locations in the east bay). I also ordered Cafe Sua (Viet coffee). 

This being SF, with the strong Chinese influence, it is common to be served a pot of tea in Vietnamese places. In the South Bay, it is more common to be served ice water in a glass. 

When I came in, everything was per Manual steps 1 and 2. I had to ask #4 for Hoy Sin, because it wasn't on every table per the manual rule number 3 Option, C above. I promptly got that from the #4. #6 did as instructed. The Matriarch settled my bill, as required in rule #5.
author: Wanugee N.

description:
I loved Kevin's Noodle House. I was feeling under the weather a few weeks ago and just wanted a big bowl of chicken noodle soup. While the chicken noodle soup I got here wasn't exactly how mom used to make, it was delicious! 

My boyfriend did not get a bowl of soup and was not as pleased with his meal, Com Suon Bi Hot Ga Op La, but did acknowledge that the soup was pretty delicious and he would be trying one of those next time.
author: Daphne W.

description: I had never tried pho before coming here but I can say that I really enjoy it! I havent tried any other pho except for other Kevins locations but if you are looking for a deal (at least it is in my opinion) then this is the place for you! Large portions for somewhat low prices.
author: Jordan K.

description:
This use to be my to-go place for a cheap meal. There's a reason why it's cheap because the quality is terrible and half the people working there don't know what they're doing. It's sad I use to be a weekly regular with my friends, but now we don't come back here for many reasons.

I usually got the pho ga tom, which is the seafood chicken soup. It's alright, but I could probably make a noodle soup just as tasty at home with half the sodium. Same with the beef pho bowls which also have some . The broth is riddled with essentially a ladle of MSG in every bowl. Now if you think food that gives you 1,000% of your daily sodium intake is bad, it gets worse.

I have gotten a disgusting amount of PLASTIC in my order one time and they did not take it off the bill or even offer a replacement bowl. The lady had the nerve to give us the STINK EYE and muttered she knew we wouldn't tip when she picked up the bill. Be LUCKY we paid at all.

There's lots of cheap pho places in SF that are equal or higher quality than Kevin's. I mainly came to Kevin' since they had more chicken selections than other places, but that's not good enough of an excuse to come back. Now that I think about it, this place is REALLY dirty and unsanitary.

Rude service, bad food. Avoid this place at all costs unless you want to choke on plastic or an MSG induced headache. This place, even though it's nothing fancy, focuses more on QUANTITY than QUALITY. 

Save your money and go to PPQ across the street for 10x better food. You'll at least get a welcome when you enter the restaurant.
author: Cindy L.

description: Medium rating for it. Taste has down grade from Last visit perhaps their chief has left
author: Quang T.

description:
In a word: Legit.

By far the best pho I've had in the city -- possibly ever. Don't expect anything too fancy regarding the table service. I wouldn't say that the service is bad by any means though. This place is strictly business, so if you come with the intention of simply having a delicious meal you're good to go.
author: Tini T.

description: Eggrolls were pretty good, crispy and satisfying. Depending on my appetite I can either devour or merely touch the edges of a bowl of pho. This time, I wanted only half a serving. I was glad they let me order from the kids menu, $4 for a petite bowl that did just the job! Decent pho tai and service is really quick.
author: Briget P.

description:
Very consistent, fast service.  Great place for noodles in soup.
When the boss lady is not there, the new hostess is a little eccentric.  We walked in to the half empty restaurant and ahe asked us to sign the waiting list.  Two minutes later she came back and called our name saying table for three?
author: Curtis L.

description:
Came here on a cold day for a bowl of warm pho. I ordered #13, with medium rare beef flank and brisket. The broth was okay, but not the best that I have had so far. But I like their rice noodle a lot! It's very chewy and was cooked perfectly! 

We came in around 7 pm and there wasn't any wait. The toilet was horrible though, they didn't seem to clean it up frequently.
author: Angel T.

description: It's good, you guy should try to eat Pho with beefsteak and eggs
author: Nguyen T.

description:
Whenever I come back to the city, theres one thing I crave and ONE thing only. It gots to be the PHO!! Between 19th and 20th Ave on Irving, there are 2 pho joints that compete in the battle of the PHO - KEVINS VS PPQ.. and this is how it goes down:

Broth - Kev wins, hands down. Kevs is richer, fuller, greasier, and just overall more satiating for the belly.  PPQs broth is cleaner and "healthier", if you're down for that.

Beef - PPQ wins, hands down. Getting beef on the side, you can def tell the difference. PPQ is bright red and fresh. Kevs may have a little brown ring around the edges.

Rice plates - PPQs charbroiled meats are BOMB, along with their imperial roll. Never tried Kevs but they have egg rolls instead of imperial rolls. Not a fan.

Cleanliness- Kevs for the tables, utensils, menus and bathroom. PPQ may be sticky icky icky with tore up utensils and pubes sprinkled on the menus. 

Service - Kev, for they understand English (HUGE PLUS) and will respond WITH urgency to our overwhelming demands for extra onions/cilantro, jalepenos, water, and tea. Also, service is fast, we were waved down to a table the second we stepped thru the door-homie saw us coming from outside! PPQ is hit or miss. You may have to wave your arm and remind the server you're waiting for a table when its busy. Your server will most likely be a fob*, so beware when making special requests, only 50% of them will be understood but they'll say yes and nod their heads to everything you say. 

Parking - is a bizitch either way. Prepared to get sick driving round n round in circles.

Hours- PPQ is open about 1/2 hr later.

Bottom line: My heart will always have a special place for PPQ, but right now, Kevin satisfies the soul more .. & thats soul pho real.
author: Angela W.

description:
This place was a mistake. 

I got a pho and fresh spring rolls. The spring rolls came out right away but it lacked cilantro/basil and it was bland. No sign of the lettuce being washed because there was no remanence of water....unless the rice paper and the noodles had soaked up the water because it was pre-made a while ago. Yuck. Pho was ok, but not the best I've had. 

Also, it's NOT on the menu but if you add thing to your pho (i.e. tendon/tripe/meat) it's an extra $2.00.
author: Momoe K.

description:
A little hungover, don't want the hassle of cooking or going out to eat?  This is a great place to affordably pick up some food to go.  There pho and noodles are both quite good. 

With a bevy of Pho options in the Sunset (I accidentally went into the one right across the street at first), this is a solid option.  Large portions for relatively cheap.
author: Adam Z.

description: Great pho, low prices, and quick service.  I'm sure I could write a more long winded review, but honestly that's all you need to know about this place.
author: Joshua W.

description:
I'm from San Jose, so I like to think I know my pho.

This is hands down the best place in SF for pho. Their other noodle dishes are excellent as well (hu tieu nam vang, and etc). Just too bad they don't have bun bo hue. It's cheap too, and takes card. Sometimes there's a wait too, esp during busy hours, but that's my only complaint. 

This place is good. Sorry yummy yummy, I aint seeing you guys no more.
author: Kevin W.

description:
Cheap and descent Pho. It'll fix a craving but it won't be the most amazing Pho you've ever eaten. 

Would I go back; yes. Would I still look for other places; yep.
author: Asa R.

description: Just like the other joint in Daly City. Yummy Pho, cheap prices, plenty of ingredients and good portions of meat and noodles. Perfect spot to warm up walking around cold, soggy and foggy sunset.
author: Eui O.

description: After a game, this place is a great place to chat with teammates over a bowl of pho. The pho is your everyday pho, but it's the people you eat with that makes the meal special. Kevin's has the space for this to happen, with plenty of room for your team.
author: Ian W.

description: When I eat Pho, i look for portion sizes, broth, cost, and iced coffee.  Just to say it short, it was on point for all of them.  I thought the cost was reasonable, and the portions was huge.  perfect for the rainy day I tried it on.  Paired with a good Vietnamese Iced coffee and I was stuffed.  Thank you!
author: Jonathan V.

description: I have been coming here consistently since 2009 and the food is always on point. Vietnamese food is my comfort food and this is always my togo. Order the #1 and you won't regret it. Service is quick and food comes out fast (at least for the #1) comes out within 5 minutes of ordering! The plate of veggies they give you to put in your soup is also very fresh, unlike some other places that give you old or reused ones. Test it if it's fresh by snapping the bean sprout in half, should be a easy bend and water will pop out. This place gets busy on weekends, but the turnover rate for tables are quick. Make sure to put your name on the clipboard on the front. Parking is a bit hard since it's located on the busy streets of Irving but this place is worth the hassle. They have really good blended drinks too! I suggest trying the avocado or jackfruit shake. Made with real ingredients. The crab cakes are also the best ones I've ever had! Honestly, everything is good here and decently priced. I do wish they had bun rieu though. Oh yeah, this location is also better than the one in Daly City. They have everything on a system and ready to go. Quick, quick, super quick!
author: Helen C.

description:
Stopped by for lunch with the family. Pho with beef and brisket #13 was above average. Lots of noodles, an average portion of meat, and tasty broth. Wasn't thirsty afterwards so MSG content was reduced if not eliminated from the recipe. 

Red bean/coconut milk smoothie #75 was better than expected. Three color drink was sweet with a good portion of mung bean and tapioca jelly, but not much red beans. 

Egg noodles seafood combination #26 was also a good choice. Noodles were a bit tough if you or your child do not have teeth, but tasted great regardless. 

The waitress, tall, young woman, was prompt and efficient. Didn't question me when I asked for scissors to cut the noodles for my mother.

Good service, delicious food and decent ambiance.  Biggest plus? Clean utensils! That pushed the rating from 4 to 5 stars.
author: W G.

description:
When I lived in Socal, pho tasted the same everywhere. Pho was pho. It was good. It was cheap. It was filling. It was a staple in my diet. Then I had pho in the vietnamese area (Westminster/Garden Grove) and I realized some pho could taste better than others!

And then I moved up to norcal.. and was like...wtf.....pho could also taste worse than others. :\

Yes, I'm sad to say that all of the pho places I've tried up in norcal have been mediocre at best. It is not my first preference when picking out a restaurant.. until I heard about this Pho Huynh Hiep 2.. Also known in my mind as Restaurant #2. (I never knew it was called Kevin's Noodle House.. must have missed the sign). I see it all the time while driving along Irving. Plenty of people have told me that I should try it or that next time we stop by I'll try... Well FINALLY.. I have tried it.. and so far it is the best pho place I have been to in Norcal. It is not the best pho I have ever had.. I'm forever ruined by Westminster/Garden Grove pho.. but.. damn .. the broth here.. it's great!!

I think I came back again within the same week. That's how good it was!! I miss you good pho place... T_T

Sooo...... $5-$6 for a small bowl of pho.. so cheap! and so good! It's not gonna stuff you silly.. sorry to say. But it is filling! And if its not filling..then..uhh..drink the broth! And if that's not enough for you then..uhh..drink the water!!! Or if all else fails.. order the spring rolls!! Those are always yummy in my tummy... :)

Maybe I should be going to San Jose for my pho fix. Seems like that's where all my ViEt hoMiEz live. Haha, jk, sorry I'll never do that again...
author: Stephanie W.

description: this spot just hits the spot when it comes to affordable and hunger. sometimes after a workout I'd come here and eat away. The dude cleaning the tables with hot tea cracks me up because he looks around to see if anyone is looking, ew.
author: Paulo R.

description:
This place is my absolute favorite for a combo beef pho with everything. I used to live in the neighborhood and now I'm at least 25 mins away but it's still worth it to make the drive.

I especially like how they keep things simple and fresh, that they give you tons of basil, and that none of their condiments have a stale smell (many pho places in this price range don't meet that requirement). And fast service even when it's packed. And the sweet old lady who makes sure you get your tea :)
author: S. A. K.

description:
Coming from SoCal, I have had some amazing pho, and I must say, Pho Huynh Hiep 2 is actually pretty good!!

The best part about this restaurant is the large portions! For most of the items on their menu, you can order a small, medium or large. I ordered a large  for $8.50 and the bowl was HUGE!! Whenever I come here, it seems like most people order the medium because most people wouldn't be able to finish the large in one sitting. On average, the large costs $7.50. 

Service is also very fast! On their busy nights, I have waited less than 10 minutes for my order. On their slower nights, I guarantee you that your order will come in less than five minutes. 

I also love that they put the mint, cilantro and bean sprouts on the side. I have been to pho restaurants where there is too much or too little mint, cilantro and/or bean sprouts, so for them to have these items on the side was a great idea. 

I only have two complaints, which also explains the -1 star:

1) I wish they added more noodles. The amount of meat is great, but if they are going to serve me a huge bowl, I would hope that they would put enough noodles to fill it and not just serve me a bowlful of broth. 

2) The boba is gross. If you really want boba, just walk down the street to Tpumps. I ordered the mango boba and it was chalky to the point where I could taste the powder. For a second there I thought I was drinking my boyfriend's protein shake.
author: Mark B.

description: Love the pho here! It's totally one of the best pho I've ever had in SF! The restaurant was always busy when I was there though. So there would probably a little wait but it's totally worth it!
author: Ruby N.

description:
This place is the tits (the mutt's nuts if you're British). 

Don't read any more reviews and compare - it's a waste of time when you could be on your way over. 

Yes, I drive across town for this place.
author: Emmie Y.

description: It was good. I enjoyed it. But really, it wasn't anything special, and it didn't blow me away. There are better Vietnamese restaurants around, but if you're in the neighborhood, this one is "fine". That's the word for it, really... it's "fine".
author: Sean B.

description: My go to pho spot in the city! Very quick service, and delicious boba drinks.  Pro tip: You have to ask for water otherwise they won't bring it out.
author: Rose V.

description:
We came here upon the recommendation of a coworker. The service here was excellent. We were promptly seated when we arrived. We made our orders and literally WITHIN ONE MINUTE our order was served. We ordered 2 bowls of pho and it was prepared to exactly what you expect pho to be.

The restaurant has a typical Vietnamese pho restaurant feel to it but very spacious. There is plenty of staff to accommodate for the large crowds, although I did have to request water. As for the price, it is great value. You would be hard pressed to find pho anywhere in SF for sub $6.50 prices. That, alone, will get me to come back. The pho itself was delicious although you could taste the after effects of MSG later on in the evening. The vermicelli noodles were aplenty but could be cut up a bit; it was all bunched up together and hard to bite into. 

Great, speedy experience. It is the perfect place for a quick meal!
author: Jimmy D.

description: Solid Pho for the Price. I want to say this is probably one of my favorite to go to pho spots in San Franicsco. Located near many milk tea spots, it is the perfect combination with this pho. They are generous with their amount of serving and tastes one of the best. I go to school at san jose state and not most of the pho in san jose can not compare with kevins noodle. Well recommended for cold days and HANGOVERS.
author: Auden W.

description:
What are the words that come to your mind when you think of a pho spot? I think comforting, fast, delicious, cheap, homey, and generous.  Kevin's Noodle House has all those. 

THE NOODLES:

Super deep menu with tons of options, I had a pork and fish cake noodle soup, and my girlfriend had the chicken pho.  Often the toppings can be an afterthought, but the items here are individually seasoned and well thought out, the pork was tender, and the cakes had a great flavor to them. Medium sized bowls are gigantic. Broth is clean and delicious, could be more complex but it hit the spot. 

THE RESTAURANT:

Laid back and full of happy people, incredibly quick service and cheap prices. Couldn't ask for more.
author: Patrick T.

description:
We eat here all the time.  It is Jr. Yelpers' favorite pho restaurant but they don't order the pho, they like the 5 spice BBQ chicken over rice. I like their seafood or chicken with pork pho.  The broth is very flavorful.  They give you an accompanying plate with bean sprouts, thai basil (they used to give a lot more of this stuff), sliced jalapenos, (to save $ and resources, they should ask if folks even WANT this because we never eat it) and cilantro.
A small bowl is plentiful for me but depending on Hubby's appetite, he may order a medium or a large. We did have an order of spring roll, 3 pieces (the rice wrapper) filled with mostly lettuce and some shrimp with a peanut topped hoisin-like tasting sauce for dipping.
Service is quick (we did have to remind them of the spring roll order which arrived late) and turnover is quick.  No matter which day of the week (even weekdays), they're always busy.  The younger generation of workers there has updated the technology to using mini iPads to place your order but not for paying your bill.

You run into all types eating here of various ethnicity. Next to us was a group a guys who may be on a budget eating size small bowls - one remarked how he worked at Mollie Stone's for 8 yrs after 2 yrs of college and can't leave because no one else pays what he makes as a shift supervisor.  But, his current job doesn't pay enough.  The current sad state of economics and employment in SF. So, if you don't mind sitting close to other diners, this is the kind of conversation you may overhear at meal time.
author: Ry T.

description: A Richmond classic. Don't know anyone that doesn't love this place. Delicious, affordable. What more do you need? I also appreciate being able to choose the size of your meal!
author: Anna T.

description: Lots of seating, fast service, great prices, and an amazing selection. My go-to Pho spot in the city!
author: Kirill P.

description: Their noodles are great, but the service is ok. The restaurant gets packed so it gets stuffy and the waiters brought the bill to us before we even finished our food. They get busy, so I guess they try to kick the customers that are finishing up out.
author: Angel N.

description: Once you get past the wait times (10-15 minute wait during lunch hours), service is pretty quick. The broth is on the thinner side, but aromatic. If you're feeling dehydrated, and want broth but don't want a giant bowl of noodles, just order a smaller sized bowl of pho and tack on a side of meat ball/tripe/tendon (~$2.50). The sides come in a small bowl of broth, so ta-daaa, extra fluids for your hungover tuchas. Don't expect to get water refilled unless you flag a server down. Expect to spend about $13/head if you're going with an entree and a drink, which comes with quick service. -1 star because ventilation can be bad (it feels like heaven on stuffy days when a guest opens the door to come in), and your clothes will smell after.
author: Andrew L.

description:
UNNGGGHHHH!!!!! 

Ahem. I digress. 

Spookily, I wrote my first review for Kevin's Noodle House almost exactly a year ago. Here I am to reassert my feelings. This place reigns supreme in Delicious Town. You really must make a pilgrimage if your taste buds value pho at all. The food is delicious, packed with flavor, and the service makes sure it reaches your table in record time. No frills, no fuss, and extremely wallet-friendly, Kevin will fill you up with so much hot steamy goodness. You heard me. 

Small #17 for lyfe.
author: Chelsea B.

description: Had a really good price for the pho and rice plates. Not overly charged like some other pho places I've been to. The pho broth is really good, but the noodles had a really peculiar taste. Can't really put my tongue on it, but it's still good. The "rare steak" was not rare. They put the beef in too early or cooked it for me because it was fully well done cooked by the time I got it. The medium was satisfying but it kind of seemed like they just gave me a bigger bowl with more soup, so next time I'd just stick with the small. Parking: you're in sf so it's kind of difficult. :P have fun.
author: Michelle Y.

description: I'm going to keep this review short...BEST BROTH ever. Been to many pho places and nothing compares to here. Whether its the beef or the chicken flavor. Love the service and the food. You can choose from 3 different sizes. Service and atmosphere is great. Prices are just right. Been here way too many times surprised i never wrote a review for this place.
author: Danny F.

description:
Call me clingy...but I can't be separated from my comforting bowl of noodle soup on Sunday mornings, particularly depending on the series of events I'm so indulgent in on Saturday nights. 

I come to Kevin's mainly because they make solid food for a decent price. It's a few blocks down from the famous Yummy Yummy, but the parking between here and there can be on completely different spectrums.Their menu selection for Vietnamese food is big - you have your noodle soups, rice plates, appetizers, and refreshments. Their portions are proportionate to many other Vietnamese noodle houses and I always leave feeling full and satisfied. 

Some of my favorite dishes from here would have to be the Beef Stew with ho fun, Seafood Combination Noodle Soup, and their Combination Rice Plate. Their beef stew was moist, tender and easy to chew. Lots of meat variety in their seafood combination. Plus, their rice plate combo is great - they cook their pork chops nicely; seasons perfectly and isn't dry (kudos since it's so easy to overcook pork chops!). 

All in all, I am very grateful to have Kevin in my life. Wherever you are, whoever you are, thanks for making life a bit easier (and warmer!) as I eat happily while staring at the cloudy and foggy skies of Sunset.
author: Regina C.

description:
So my family and I have been coming here for a couple of years now for pho. The first time I came here was when I KNEW this was the best pho place in San Francisco. (my favs are in San Jose, y'all should go there and eat bun mam) So this year, I've experienced RUDENESS from this ONE specific waiter or table cleaner, TWICE. 
                  
The first experience was when I went there with my FAMILY and we forgot which order was who's. After a few seconds of figuring out who ordered what and the guy serving us was about to leave, he mumbled in vietnamese " Wow, these people don't even know what they ordered." This man thought I didn't know vietnamese, but I understood everything he said. I left a penny for his shitty service and I usually leave $2-3 tip (i'm not an adult yet) 

I just recently went there a week ago after testing with my friends to enjoy a lunch and chat together. We got seated and in 3 minutes, we knew what to order. After 5 minutes trying to get someone to take our order, raising my hand to get someone's attention, but nobody came. The SAME RUDE man, looked at me and said " ORDER?" I nodded and he gave me this RUDE attitude with his hand gestures and said " OKAY." he pointed over to another worker which seems to be the ONLY one taking people's order. We waited about 10 minutes for him to come. Like, YALL WORK AT THE SAME DAMN PLACE, CUSTOMERS ARE WAITING, HELP EACH OTHER OUT. It don't matter what kind of shift that rude ass guy was on, he was standing there chatting with another worker CHILLIN. He's lucky he didn't serve me because I wouldve gave him 1 cent tip . 

The man is lucky that the family business does not have name tags or i'd put him on blast here in hopes he gets fired. This man is usually the guy that passes out food or cleans up tables.
author: Josie D.

description: I love this place, I'm a regular. Great pho, vermicelli, and they bring your food out hella quick (5-10 mins). Parking sucks of course, because it's located in SF. I always come here, sometimes with friends or to get food to-go. But what the hell. The last time I ordered vermicelli with BBQ pork and eggrolls, I asked for two plastic sauce cups from the cashier after I payed and didn't tip (Do I have to tip if I'm ordering to-go??). I think he saw that I didn't tip him and got mad. So he said he can only give me one cup and that I don't need any more sauce because it already comes with the fish oil sauce. UM! I can eat my vermicelli however I want, with as much Sriracha and oyster sauce as I want homeboy! And why you so cheap on me, can't give me a second sauce cup?! My gosh, you have so much business and probably make thousands a day! Another worker interrupted and gave me two sauce cups, bless his soul. Sheesh.
author: Shirla S.

description:
Great place for recovery food, warm delicious Pho, fairly fast service however bummed they couldn't add extra vegetables since they did have any on hand.   

Also got some good shrimp spring rolls. Which were very fresh. The peanut sauce was too salty for me and not creamy enough but my friend said he enjoyed it.
author: Michelle D.

description: Best hangover cure. I always get the medium #2. Their portions are huge. The medium is a large to me and the large is super sized.
author: Lisa L.

description:
I used to come here aaallllllllll the time and I always got their rice plates with shrimp wrapped in tofu skin. It's the one Vietnamese place in San Francisco that did it well. Then the price went up, up, up over the years and neither my sister nor I went to Presidio anymore so there was less incentive to go across city for it. (And because we found Ben Tre - http://bitly.com/1bUXRcO)

I came by recently for my pho craving after a late night out and even decided to wait 45 minutes just to get it. I've never waited for this place before. Ever. But I guess it's because of all the kiddos who were out on New Years Eve (hah, I guess that's including me too). When my bowl of pho arrived, I must say... I was a bit disappointed. There wasn't much beef and even less noodles, especially for the price. The broth was still good though. 

But I think I've strayed away from the good Vietnamese places in the city solely because of the price to quality ratio. I can get good food with larger portions for cheaper elsewhere (like San Jose, for instance). This place was a nice pastime. It's too bad everything in San Francisco just costs so much more now.
author: Sandy T.

description:
I LOVE this place!

When your menu has 100 different items to choose from and pretty much all of them are good, you cannot lose!!  You cannot go wrong with the standard Pho, or something like a rice plate with 5 items.  Once you finish scratching your head on what to get to eat, you can do the same on choosing a drink!  Great place, and always a go to when I am around the area.
author: Bernie C.

description: I had a satisfying meal of beef stew with rice noodles for a Tuesday 1pm lunch. The broth was flavorful, stronger than Pho broth, and the beef was tender. We also has egg rolls, which were good, but not as impressive as the beef stew. My lunch date had a pork chop with egg and rice. It was good too. The service was prompt and courteous. The restaurant was busy but not so busy. It was a good time to go.
author: Little M.

description: My go to pho place! Love the pho here, great value and big portions. I live two blocks from here and eat here pretty often. I'd recommend any of the pho (both beef and chicken broth are great) and the shrimp cakes. Yum!
author: Julia P.

description: I'm not vietnamese, but this pho place is FAST beyond belief and has great pho.
author: Pj A.

description:
I seriously come here just about every week. I'm not a pho fan at all but I just love the egg noodles and broth here-just never fails. 
Pros: Great pho!!! They are always quick and efficient to get the orders right. Their boba drinks are always well blended with soft boba
Cons: If you're looking for something fancy, this is not the place.  It is always crowded and sometimes I need to share tables (but that's ok because the food's worth it!)
author: Graciel T.

description: Had the five spice chicken vermicelli. The chicken was very dry, the lettuce wasn't on the fresh side. Meh.
author: Hila S.

description:
oh Kevin's Noodle House... I really can always depend on you for comforting Vietnamese food. Seriously, it's rare to find a restaurant that satisfies my spoiled palate raised on Mama's cooking.

Although they recently upped all their prices by a $1 in the past few months, everything is still under $8-9. I always go for their Bun Bo Hue, although their chicken rice dishes are yummy too!

Sidenote: I personally prefer this over the more popular and rivaling PPQ directly across the street.
author: Andrew T.

description:
Kevin's Noodle House is MY SPOT.  It is always the go-to place my friends and I hit up when we're craving some pho or Viet food.

The service is pretty on point. Even on their most busiest days, we've been seated within 20 mins at the most, and the food usually comes out in 10 mins.  The place itself is very clean, which I do enjoy as well.

Now, the food:  I usually order the #2 medium, which is my favorite.  The broth is the best, and there is always the right amount of broth-noodle-meat within the dish.  I also have gotten the #1 XL (which is like the #2, but in a bigger bowl), which is definitely more bang for your buck, especially if your hungry.  Another favorite of mine are the fried egg rolls, which are delicious! The prices are relatively cheap when it comes to pho as well...just another reason why this is my favorite pho spot in SF!
author: Megan K.

description: Pretty solid spot for vietnamese food in the sunset - I would definitely come back to try some of their specialty dishes (e.g. dry noodles). They don't have bún bò hu probably because of difference in region I would assume, but nonetheless they have enough choices on their menu to make everyone happy. You can even order a small bowl of pho AND have vermicelli spring rolls without feeling too full at all. I like the different size option for sure.
author: Jackie C.

description: No frills place but who wants that with pho. Good, fast, dependable. Perfect hangover food, perfect Karl the Fog blues, just perfect.
author: Kristan B.

description:
Favorite pho place in the city... Probably the country too. 

Service is so attentive and things come quickly. However, if you want to take your time you're never pressured to leave. 

The food is consistent in quality, prob 4 or 4.5 stars, but this place gets 5 stars because of the service and price-- pretty inexpensive and you leave feeling stuffed. 

Their incredibly accommodating like if you have a large party they'll make it happen. They're rice/vermicelli plates are also good too
author: Malia B.

description: noodles were kind of soft and mushy and the broth tasted overly salted. I think they cut you a little short on the meat as well. The summer roles were also kind of lack luster. On the plus side, the service is really fast.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I haven't been here since 2007. Can I just tell you how packed it was at lunch... CRAZY... They even have a sign in sheet and people willing to wait. 

Turn around time to get a table was pretty quick. It only took us 10 min to get seated and we were the 4th ones on the list.

I ordered the #5 medium size with no tripe. A lot of the other Pho spots have bland broths and my favorite use to be Jasmine Garden in SF until today. This broth had so much flavor before I dressed it up. After dressing up my pho with the hoisen, siracha, and chili oil it was 100X better then it was already. I could have ate it without doing putting anything in it but I love my food spicy.

People here are super friendly unlike the majority of the Pho restaurants around DC or SF... It sucks that this place is so deep into the city other wise I would be here all the time. :-(
author: Cel Y.

description:
My favorite pho place in SF (there's one in DC too) and it happens to be a block away from my favorite boba place. 

Love this place because they're crazy fast and delicious and super affordable. What else can be said. The pho is on point, I always add extra lime because I like my pho sour. I probably come here like once a week and the place is always consistent (actually I'm pretty sure they always seat me at the same table haha) and always delicious.
author: Devyn P.

description:
A group of us came here for lunch and ordered several bowls of pho. There was almost no tripe in the bowl, like they had forgotten to add it.  When we questioned the waiter about his, he came over and insisted that it was in there. We finally found a few shreds at the bottom of the bowl. Wow! Really! And your attitude leaves much to be desired.

Very disappointing. We won't be coming back. Should have gone to PPQ across the street
author: Brig E.

description:
So this vietnamese restaurant is obviously good - the other reviews here speak for themselves. However, it can be difficult to find a great pho restaurant that can be satisfying for vegetarians as well. This place definitely does not have a "vegetarian friendly" section like a lot of newer asian restaurants in sf. But... the staff here is really accommodating and willing to make substitutions on a lot of their menu items. 

VEGETARIANS: I would recommend getting the fresh rolls veggie style. They replace the shrimp with the holy grail of any veggie dish: AVOCADO. Mmmm! Also, I recently discovered that if you get the number 48 (Bún Ch Giò -Fried egg roll, lettuce, carrot, peanut w/ vermicelli) you can sub a couple fried eggs for the egg roll. This makes a really fresh and satisfying vermicelli salad. Tastes great with some sriracha, plum sauce, peanut sauce... any and all of it. 

I am happy to say I can come here with all my friends slurping beef pho and feel totally satisfied with my own meal :)
author: Jasmine M.

description:
This is my "go-to" place whenever I am in the mood for pho. I have absolutely zero complaints about this place and I have been coming here for a few years now.

I usually get the #2 which is a combo with beef brisket, tripe, meatballs, and tendon in a beef broth. The meat is always tender and well flavored. The best part however, is the broth. Unlike most places, the broth isn't drenched in MSG and doesn't leave you thirsty for hours after you eat. 

On occasion, I get the #31 which is a wide egg noodle in a beef stew. The beef stew is very hearty with a heavy tomato flavor. It's very delicious when I want something more savory than the usual light beef broth.

The service is also great and quick. My food always comes out within ten minutes and the price is very reasonable too: about $10/person.

If you're ever in the area and in search of pho, I would highly recommend Kevin's Noodle House.
author: Ray W.

description:
My go-to place for Pho. 
It's good.
It's fast. 
They're friendly. 
They take credit card. 
You see some hot, possibly jail-bait, chicks once in awhile.
author: Garland W.

description: This is hands down my favorite Vietnamese restaurant in SF. My favorite is the beef stew (31, 32, or 33... They vary  the noodles, but the beef and stew is the same).
author: Simon L.

description:
Favorite pho spot and come here monthly! I've had PPQ, Golden Star, and places in San Jose but nothing compares to Kevin's. Food is consistent. 

Pro-tip: Ask for the meat on the side!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
What happened?!

I have some fond memories of eating at Kevin's Noodle House over the years. Post study session dinners, iphi dinner meetings, and many over eventful occasions were celebrated with a piping hot bowl of pho in the outer sunset.

Came here last Friday because we were all craving pho but for some reason, everything fell short of good.

The waiter got our order wrong. We all got medium bowls but was surprised by the small noodle portion size compared to the large bowl size. My friend actually asked if I had any food at home and came over after dinner to have dinner #2. The beef was chewy and tough. For the first time, I noticed flies hovering above our heads in the restaurant. 

It was a strange day- I felt like I got trapped in a warped world where pho was destined to be bad. Maybe I will give Kevin's Noodle House another try one of these days but for now, I'm going to stick with the place across the street.
author: Gloria C.

description: This is one of my favorite places for pho. Usually a lot of pho places in the city are dirty, but I feel like Kevin's does a better job than most places to keep their restaurant clean. The service is pretty good, and their pho is extraordinary. Not only that, but the prices are very affordable and much better than the $9-10 you can pay at other places.
author: Celina W.

description: Everytime I'm in town I make a stop here for a very good bowl of pho, and it's always packed. One of the best locations for this ever-expanding chain.
author: John B.

description:
I got "scolded" for not signing a waiting list even though there is no one ahead of me and plenty of empty tables available. I signaled the waiter twice that there are two people in my party. He did not acknowledge me the first time so I didn't know if he heard me. When I signaled again with two fingers, he snapped at me. I told him that I wasn't in a rush or anything. I didn't know if he had heard me. He then said I needed to sign in on the waiting list. 

I usually write only good reviews and not a complaint. But this dude was seriously rude.  I know business is good but it's important to treat your customers with respect. I urge the owner to review their operating procedures and retrain their staff (their son to be exact). 

Good business might not stay forever. Don't get too sassy at an early age.

There is PPQ across the street that offers bigger portion. The pho noodle isn't chewy like it is here. The pho broth is clearer, less MSG and they use angus beef. The only disadvantage is their place is smaller so you have to wait in line longer. I will go to PPQ from now on.
author: Monique N.

description:
Yummy! This place has pretty bomb pho. The broth is the perfect amount of salty however it was pretty oily and that was a little bit of a turn off for me. On the other hand the noodles were really fresh and cooked perfectly. They will also LOAD YOU UP WITH MEAT. And the whole thing costs like $6. There's really no excuse to dislike this place.

It can get pretty busy. We came on Saturday at 1pm and had to wait about 10-15 mins for a table even though the place is huge! Although, once we ordered, our pho appeared within 10 minutes. MAGICAL. Service was quick and attentive and we appreciated that a lot.

Parking in this area is a total bitch but at least you know you're gonna be well rewarded with pho once you find a space. Also T-pumps is one street over!
author: Alli Q.

description:
Lots of people loitering outside, you think there's a line but there isn't, just walk in.

4 of us:
- #1 XL pho with tripe, bean sprouts, various meats... http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Bfc3RwM7UAEohk9e19Q1xw?select=pLFp-BrLFH1GBFjNhkojJw
- #20 kid size pho with beef balls http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Bfc3RwM7UAEohk9e19Q1xw?select=i9Tc02nixsrhmzhvgy6GGg
- (2) #52A rice noodles with beef, carrots, various greens & a spring roll http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Bfc3RwM7UAEohk9e19Q1xw?select=IPhpTLISm1FMIodFxmV_0A

Everything was good.
We were all stuffed.
All Kevin noodle houses are reliable and delicious.
This one is less cramped than the one at Westlake.

5 stars: no wait, food comes out fast, cheap, & delicious.
author: Kylie L.

description: this has always been a staple for me for years, lately the lines have been "Hamilton" like and i wanted to know why, and now i know why, outstanding from start of service to end of meal... if in the hood, go no where else, this is the place and only place for Pho and the like .. will get a fifth star when they cross the 40 years in business ... stellar
author: tim y.

description:
As a Kevin's regular, you may find this review a little biased. Reader discretion advised. 

I've been going to Kevin's for over 6 years now. I go pretty often at least once a week and I'm always satisfied when I leave. Im always seated quickly and without hesitation by the waiters. The service can seem a little shitty if you don't understand Vietnamese culture, but the food always comes out quick. I always order the number 1 extra large and it comes out within 5 minutes of my ordering. The soup is full of flavor and delicious condiments. Kevin's has perfected that Vietnamese pho noodle and has it down to a science. For their rice plates, their pretty good too. But if you go to a pho restaurant, you better be ordering some pho. 


If you want to add to your experience if your a tourist, I'd suggest you order some milk tea from the nearby places before you go into Kevin's. Nothing beats a big bowl of pho and a large bubble milk tea.
author: Irving C.

description: Today I had a chance to spend time with my family and my brother required to eat some Vietnamese food in San Francisco, in doing so he stumbled upon this restaurant and decided to come three hours out of our way through traffic to eat here. Was it worth it? Eh, we were all very hungry but we learned our lesson in leaving the house around noon and being stuck in endless traffic for food. I ordered the Hu Tieu Dai? It's the clear noodles combination soup (#25), I personally would rank it 7.5/10 because it isn't half bad especially since I was hungry so everything was good to me at that time. They have this same business in Oakland but I heard that it was shut down for unsanitary purposes, not shocked at all but this place is slightly cleaner and efficient except for their bathrooms... Oh and touching the condiments left my fingers feeling gross and icky. I wished yelp did half stars for the ranking but whatever, it would've been a 3.5 stars if possible.
author: Jenny T.

description: Too good. Go Kevin and Chris! Tasty, affordable, clean pho. You can't go wrong.  Food comes out super fast. I always get a large #13. Super generous meat portions. And rolls and shrimp cakes make for good appetizers.
author: David D.

description: I freakin love this place! A good balance of soup taste and noodles when it comes to the pho. They rice plates are also on point! They have a generous serving of meat veggies egg and soup with their rice plates! Always a lot of room to sit! A great place for families, teenagers and yuppies. Hella good looking Asian girls that go here too not gonna lie...
author: Nicholas G.

description:
The best Pho/Vermicelli spot on Irving. 

Pho broth is always flavorful and the grilled meat they use is so delicious.  

I like this place because there's never a wait.
author: Andrew V.

description:
Pho as good as you will get in the Sunset. I really liked the broth! They also substitute fat noodles for the regular pho noodles. Always a plus in my book!

I got the #9, medium bowl and I couldn't finish it.

Good for hang over days!
author: Song C.

description:
Saturday night during Outside Lands Music Festival in Golden Gate Park was an extremely cold one. So, we left a little early for pho (only open until 10pm). 

We were seated within 5 minutes. ordered right away (chicken pho, shrimp pho and fried shrimp cakes). 

Food came out quickly an tasted delicious. I have had better shrimp cakes, but the pho did it's job and wasn't pricey. 

I also ordered a Thai tea to go, also good.
author: Chrissy E.

description: Very poor food, service and the manager is just a joke. I'm regular here, but things are falling apart and deteriorating fast in this place. Ordered my usual seafood pho with egg noodle. It tasted so bad, I almost threw up. My wife ordered the same dish and she agreed with me. It truly tasted like one year old noodle with fungus and cat pee on it. Ok, maybe both of us accidentally got the bad batch. Tried to talk to this 'manager' about the taste. He looked at me like I'm making up stories here. Asked him to give me the menu so that I can order different dish. He throws it to me as if I'm begging for food with disgusted look on him. No apologies, not a word, only very disgusting attitude. Beware, people. I don't expect good service from this kind of restaurant, but only I expected minimum, and they didn't even meet my minimal expectation. Simply, don't go there !!
author: Seokyoung C.

description: Love the stewed beef pho. Very flavorful and they get it out to you right away. Also had the fresh spring rolls, which were, of course, delicious. Usually I can't finish even a small bowl of pho, but I loved Kevin's so much that this time I conquered that soup!
author: Jen W.

description: My FAVORITE pho place in the city: definitely some of the best pho I've ever had! Most of the time there's a wait, but I've never waited more than 15-20 minutes and it's totally worth it. The boba is great too.The place is small, and there is a quick table turnover so if you're looking for a place to spend a long time at, this isn't it. Tip: Stick to the beef broth... the chicken broth isn't half as good.
author: Emily A.

description:
Walking into the restaurant, everything seem so dim. The mood of the environment seemed to be really depressing as well. The workers didn't really have a friendly greeting when we walked through the doors. It was more like they just wanted to get the job done. Service was semi-quick. However, the vegetables that came with our pho looked looked really unappetizing. I've definitely had better pho.. 

Probably will not be returning.
author: Lisa L.

description:
There are many pho places in San Francisco, but only one really does satisfy the soul. Like this one. 
 
Four stars because; 1. Customer Service is on point, they greet you as you walk in and ask the quantity of your party. They also ask you if everything is alright when you're eating. This place is usually good for groups. They have numerous tables for eight and parties of four. The wait time isn't long if it's full. Come here around 3pm/4pm and it won't be as crowded lol 2. Food quality is great, I usually get the #1 or #2. The beef broth in the pho is good. And the vermicelli is also so so good. I suggest getting it if you're craving for beef and it's ugh so good. 3. Cleanliness of this restaurant is pretty good. I've been many restaurants all around the city. And let me tell you that this is clean. The bathroom here is for customers only, and they have what you need and it's clean. Double yay. 4. Overall, with all this said you can see why I rated this 4 stars. Nothing really bad to say about this place. Plus the food is at a reasonable price. I most definitely will be coming back here!
author: L R.

description:
Definitely one of my favorite places to get pho in the city...you know, if I find parking. I always get a number 3 medium; it's the perfect amount of everything for you to survive the cold San Francisco nights. 

The broth is usually pretty good, a little salty sometimes but nothing that'll have you reaching for water every 5 seconds. There's always a crowd, so be prepared to wait for at least 10 minutes on a cold night. The waitstaff isn't the most attentive, so also be prepared to flag down people left and right to help you.

the bathroom is behind the little door in the corner, it's like an inhouse outhouse. Atleast, that's how I've heard it been described.
author: Tiffaney L.

description:
There is something about some Asian cultures that is really aggressive with dining out -- the way people flag down a waiter and assert exactly what they want, instead of waiting for someone to serve you and communicating in passive-aggressive niceties when they don't do it right.

The aggression, I think, is why I'm sometimes served a little slowly. I've seen families that come in after me but get served first. It's happened a couple times.

I think this is my only criticism.

The food's cheap. There's ample seating. And someone is constantly walking around all the tables, making sure people get what they ordered. So if I do wait, it's usually only like 10 minutes. The food is pretty standard Vietnamese soup, but still delish. I know it's maybe weird, but at least with their soups, I wish there was a menu option to order it without noodles. Love the Thai Iced Tea and love the lychee smoothie. Recommend the soup and fried rolls.
author: David S.

description: If you like pho, then this is the right place to go. Price is cheap and the food is delicious! I recommend this place to all pho lovers!
author: Nico T.

description: What more can I say? This location (as well as the one in Westlake) is spot on for Viet food. This is my go-to place when I'm in the area. Fast, cheap and always delicious. Never disappoints!
author: Emily C.

description: Excellent friendly service food was fresh and cooked to perfection. The beef pho and spring rolls with peanut sauce was the best I've had
author: Aubrey M.

description:
I engaged in a pho-off at Kevins involving turn up the flavour sensitivity and stumbling between Kevins and an unnamed challenger across the street. Both medium, special combo pho.

Kevin's broth made me swoon, there were far more miscellaneous tasty chunks, hell, even the hot tea had more flavour. I was skewed against Kevin's but I came around and shifted allegiances based on the undeniable disparity in quality/experience.

Ideal for rainy weather; and mucking with the broth (premature adjustment) is not recommended.
author: Donald C.

description:
I can't believe I've never written a review for this place. I'm always here. If I'm not too lazy and craving Pho, I haul ass to Kevin's. Great Pho, tons of variety and choices of meat. I hate places that had either only raw thin sliced beef or combo of everything. I'm a huge thin sliced beef and tripe guy and I like how I can point to a number to get that exact combo. I'm also in love with their spring rolls. 

If you want Pho and in the sunset, just go to Kevin's.

Oh and I almost forgot the boba drinks. They make this smoothie with tapioca and I'll admit, I become a little fatty and get the melon smoothie tapioca every time. No regrets.
author: Cody M.

description:
If you have hangover, cold or general doldrums, Pho helps cure what ails. That statement is not supported by the FDA. But, I'm a fairly trust worthy source. 

Pho Ga (chicken noodle soup) is my preference. And, it comes in small, medium or large. The large is so big it's somewhat laughable. But, if you want some leftovers, the large is good. 

I also love the fresh spring rolls. I ask them to hold the pork. And, they're cool with that.   

This spot is a gem. I love the people watching, the soup and the hot tea. This is a top Pho spot for SF.
author: Dusty B.

description:
Mmm ... On a cold day especially a day of walking all around SF, I like to come here and enjoy a nice bowl of pho. The aroma of the soup is heavenly. It really brings me back to my childhood.

The elderly lady that helped me was sweet as if she was my own grandma. It can get a bit hectic and busy so service can slack a bit but overall if you just want a quick cheap meal I suggest heading here.
author: Amber H.

description:
I've been here way too many times to count.  Really good price point for some pretty tasty pho (I usually get the Dac Biet Bo Vien (#2?) or #1 (x large)).  I've also tried the beef stewed noodles and they were pretty tasty.  

The fried chicken wings are kinda meh (not super crispy, kinda grease soaked), but the spring rolls are solid, and the rice dishes are pretty good too.  They also make a pretty good Vietnamese coffee and Thai ice tea.

As expected with this kind of food, super fast service!  We usually get our noodles about 5 minutes after ordering.
author: Max L.

description:
I love this place because it has my favorite type of noodle soup --clear noodle soup with seafood broth! Not many pho places have the clear noodle soup, and once I saw that they had it here, I knew I would continue to come here. 

Service is fast, food is cheap, and the noodles always satisfy my cravings. I've never had a problem being seated right away and having my order taken right away as well. Tea is constantly being refilled here as well.
author: Audrey C.

description:
The pho here is great!! My roommate and I were craving good pho so we made the long trip from Berkeley just to get it. That's dedication! 

There's a lot of seating and the place was packed both times I went there. However, the wait goes by fast and there's always TPumps nearby for those who want to get boba while they're waiting. Pho + Milk tea = best meal everrrr.
author: Linda Z.

description:
+ Different portion sizes available

+ Cheap

+ Super fast service.  My order came up about 30 seconds after I ordered, didn't even get a chance to finish my text.

+ Something about the nice old waiters there made the place seem a lot homey for me, like I was 7 again and back at my grandparents' house slurping noodles.

+ Pho was phoking delicious, and I was seriously tempted to drop my whole public lady-like habits and drink the bowl
author: Tian Q.

description: Beef stew with fat rice noodles!  YUM!  Price is cheap and food comes out quick!  Also try out the fried shrimp cakes.
author: E G.

description:
I measure ALL pho against this spot. None of them get near. Their broth is equisitie and really delicious. The produce, meats and sea food all appear to be very fresh and well prepared.

The lines are bonkers but they are pretty efficient. I wouldn't pay too much attention to any of the naysayers. The lines are always out the door.
author: Zach E.

description:
Great pho! I got the beef noodle soup and it was delicious! Very flavorful. A small bowl is about $6.

The place is pretty popular so be prepared to wait for a bit if you're going for dinner. However the service is quick!
author: Jaclyn N.

description: Oldie but goodie..quick easy and open early...so def. a spot I hit up  in the am.
author: Mary B.

description:
Just thinking about Kevins (which I didnt even know was the name, I always just called it the place with the red oning) puts a smile on my face. 

Lets be real - this is not some upscale bougey ass pho house that will cost you $15 dollars a bowl. This hasnt been San Francisco-fied yet. 

If what you are looking for is a killer bowl of traditional pho this is your place. The broth is so clean and delicious. I always get their #17. Its my fave and they are always consistent with how delicious it is. 

For $7 bucks, you really cant go wrong.
author: Colleen B.

description:
Have always heard the debate between this place and the famous PPQ. However, since PPQ is owned by a good friend's family, I've always been keen in being able to tell her I contribute to her college education. 

Decided to try this place today and it wasn't bad! The price was good for the amount of food you get ($6.50 for a medium bowl of pho with tripe, steak, flank, and brisket). You can't find that price very often anymore. The broth was nice and hot which was a HUGE plus cause a bowl of pho isn't the same if the soup broth is just luke warm. There was a decent amount of flavor in it and they were generous with toppings which is very rare these days. I made a mistake by not asking for my thinly sliced steak on the side cause it was way overcooked by the time I got to it. 

This place fills up quick during lunch time, but the service is also very good and they have enough workers to keep the flow going. Let's be real, might not be the GREATEST, but it does the job to cure a hangover =P
author: Johanna T.

description:
I've been here so many times I'm burned out. While the broth and noodles are great, the meat leaves something to be desired and is the main reason I don't want to go back. 

Also, it took a solid 6 months of going regularly and ALWAYS asking for a fork and water, for staff to bring one, never guaranteed both. Generally I have to walk up to the counter to ask for water and/or silverware. They're definitely very nice and busy so after the 6 month mark, they finally started realizing I always ask for water and a fork. So I finally stopped having to go up to the counter lol. 

Honestly though, that's no big deal. It's more the quality of meat I'm not too fond of, so this place has made it off my regular rotation.
author: Julie W.

description:
I was starving, so, I was willing to eat anything.

If you come here, don't expect really warm service, but the food is good.

Their noodle bowls were warm and filling, and I loved their Vietnamese coffee.
author: Bahar A.

description:
Portions have decreased and the broth has changed.

I was hoping it was a one-time thing, but my last 2 visits were downers.

Please don't ruin this for me. I neeeed this.
author: Nika M.

description:
They have one of the better Pho Ga bowls in the city. If you haven't tried it yet make it a point to give it a whirl. Had the peanut sauce as part of my appetizer and I agree with the other reviewer, it was a bit salty. 

Enjoy
author: Sean B.

description: I didn't find anything particularly special about this place, especially because I lived in San Jose for a HUGE chunk of my life. With that being said, I have very high expectations when it comes to my Vietnamese food.  I got the Hu Tieu Nam Vang and I should've known that I was going to be highly disappointed (which I was).  There was no option of having it made "dry" and there wasn't a lot in it.  Just some unimpressive pieces of meat and seafood.  I will say that their broth was pretty good... I'll just wait to go to San Jose for my Vietnamese food fix.
author: Kenitha Y.

description: I'll keep this review short and and quick, just like the wait for the food at this place. Although there were a few tables ahead of us during a Sunday lunch, we were seated in a few short minutes. After quickly choosing what to order the food came out just as fast. I have tried the regular pho, the seafood, and the chicken pho here and all of them were tasty and filling. The large bowl here is larger than most pho places I have tried.
author: Peter H.

description:
Just what we needed after a long day at Stinson and Bolinas! Pho was delish, service was fast, price was right. 

Couldn't have asked for anything more!  It warmed us to the core and I'll def be back soon.
author: Erin N.

description: I used to come here all the time to fulfill my pho desires, but recently the quality has failed to impress. I'm sad to say this no longer my go to pho establishment. The portions have gotten smaller, the broth and noodles do not compare to their previous standard, and the spring rolls were unpleasant for my taste buds. The broth was too salty and the noodles were too chewy. The spring rolls were like a bland meatloaf wrapped in crunchy dough. Overall, three stars for the old memories of how good it used to be.
author: Christie Y.

description:
I've lived in SF for 2.5 years now and have yet to have a decent bowl of pho, until I came here. Most Vietnamese pho places in the city that I've been to have been Chinese-influenced but I think the family that owns this one is actually Vietnamese (maybe that's why its good). Their broth is tasty, they give you a good amount of meat, reasonable portions and the restaurant looks clean. You can't really ask for more!

I like to get the #2 Pho Dac Biet. If you're new to trying pho, definitely try anything that says Dac Biet - it means "special" in Vietnamese...and usually means you get everything in it :)
author: V L.

description: The manager has bad attitude we signed in for 4 there was only 3 of us he couldn't even let us sit on the table with 4 seats and we could order for the fourth person instead he sat down for 2 people on 4 seats table smh I wouldn't even come here or tell me friends to come here he disrespected my mom.
author: Alfie C.

description:
1. This place is consistently good. 
2.  The service is extremely fast.  
3.They get my food out right after I order it. 
4. First pho place to take credit card? OMG! Wow. 
5. Do not get their tapioca drinks
author: Victor L.

description:
I stopped by for lunch to grab some food to go. The place was packed and super busy so I thought the foods going to be great. I order fried egg rolls, fried shrimp cake, and grilled beef and rice. The wait wasn't  too bad consider the amount of orders they had to prepare. I really loved their appetizers.  The shrimp cake was delicious!  

The only weird thing I noticed is I felt a bit nausea and shaky hours later. I think it might be the msg. Or simply the amount of fried food I ate which gave me a sodium over load. It's a good place to eat but in moderation.
author: Olivia C.

description: Let me start off, their middle bowl is pretty huge for the price of $7.25. I can't imagine the amount of pho in large bowl for only $8.50. The pho was great :) lot of people at night, so do come early before 7pm. Heir soup has lot of flavor, but I do wish that they give us more than one plate of goodies :/ all three of us had to share the sprouts, lemon, and basil. Overall it is good :) for the price and amount of pho you get in your bowl
author: Jenny Y.

description: This is one of two places where I get my Pho on.  When the craving hits - on chilly days or if I'm feeling under the weather - then I often head to Kevin's.  My fix is satisfied by a small bowl - beef and brisket.  If you have a huge appetite, then the medium and large bowls are available, but it's too much food for me.  The broth is excellent, the service is fast, and there is so much to do in the neighborhood.
author: Adam S.

description:
LOVE this  place! Great Phood! LOL

You gotta have their Lycee milkshake!
author: Lucas W.

description:
The pork chops w/ rice and egg was so-so. But the soup beside tasted good. There was onion inside.
The server was very rude when we ordered. Although there were many people waiting for him, his attitude made me feel uncomfortable.
author: Rachel L.

description:
I haven't had really good pho in San Francisco, so this place is probably one of my favorites so far. The servers are quick to take your order, it's cleaner than most and the broth is flavorful.

I always get the house special because I like all the different meats in my soup. I load the whole bowl up with the bean sprouts and basil - delicious! Add sriracha and hoisin sauce and you're golden. 

I love the location because it's near so many other things. Great way to walk off the carbs you consumed.
author: Mimi V.

description: Fast service and good food. Clean place and the iced coffee is good to perk up ur meal if ur feeling tired. I ordered #42 and it was good. The bbq pork was flavorful and the shrimp cake wasn't too oily (like some other places I've been to). Overall nice place and I would come back
author: Kris T.

description:
When I want pho, I go to Kevin's. 
Wish they were careful about sticking their thumbs into my soup though.
author: Sophia B.

description:
Good pho. The beef noodle pho and chicken noodle pho were both tasty, but noticed we had to add a little more sriracha/hoisin than needed at other pho establishments.

Service is fast and efficient, so I appreciate that. It's a good spot for decent eats if you're in the area. Irving sucks for parking though.
author: Tay R.

description: I am not impressed with this place and trying to understand why people give this place a four (4) star and if this restaurant deserves it. I'm a visitor on the area and of Vietnamese decent but OMG this place pho is gross and smell gross. The staff are super rude and unfriendly. We asked for items and never get them, and they give you attitude. The only person that will accommodate your request is the young girl there. The two main guys and old woman are so so rude and mean. Even though you speak in your own dialect, these people are just plain rude. There are better pho in LA.
author: Ms. Kare B.

description:
Favorite Pho place in the city.

I always order the Number 2 or I get the grill pork chop with rice. Their shrimp cakes are good, spring rolls are standard and they also offer a variety of other noodle soups.

It's a short description but plain and simple, Kevin's meets the expectations of your standard Pho place in terms of taste, quality, and price.

It's getting four stars because I haven't found anything else like it in the city.
author: Zu W.

description: Pho is ok but nothing special. Large fish pho, skimpy on the fish. Chicken/ beef pho is also ok. Not great pieces of chic or beef.
author: Dan S.

description:
My sisters and I come here all the time and the service is fast and efficient. Does get busy during nights

I always get the #17.
author: Daric C.

description:
